front.title: Sieve Email Filtering: External Data Extension

abstract.t: In advanced mail filtering setups, it is often convenient to store configuration data in an external data store. This document updates the Sieve filtering language (RFC 5228) with an extension to support retrieving string values from external sources. The extension supplies a new test so that external data can be examined. When the variables extension (RFC5229) is also active, the external data can also be accessed from a special variables namespace.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This is an extension to the Sieve language defined by SIEVE. It adds support for referencing externally stored named data. In the Sieve base specification such data can only be made available in a Sieve script by including it statically in the Sieve script itself. This extension adds a new test command to retrieve and evaluate data items stored externally. When the Sieve Variables extension is also active, a special variables namespace is available through which the data items can be accessed more conveniently for string substitution.

This extension is specific to the Pigeonhole Sieve implementation for the Dovecot Secure IMAP server. It will therefore most likely not be supported by web interfaces and GUI-based ManageSieve clients. This extension is primarily meant for use in global scripts that are managed by the systems administrator.

section.title: Conventions Used in This Document
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.
Conventions for notations are as in SIEVE Section 1.1.

section.title: Capability Identifier
section.t: The capability string associated with the extension defined in this document is "vnd.dovecot.extdata".

section.title: Extdata Test
section.t: The extdata test retrieves the data item specified by the item-name string from the external data store and matches it to the values specified in the key-list argument. The specified item-name MUST conform to the syntax defined in . The test succeeds if a match occurs. The type of match defaults to ":is" and the default comparator is "i;ascii-casemap".

The environment test MUST fail unconditionally if the specified data item cannot be retrieved, e.g. because it does not exist in the external data store or when the data store is not available. A script MUST NOT fail with an error if the item cannot be retrieved. This allows scripts to be written that handle nonexistent items gracefully. In particular, the test:

The "relational" extension adds a match type called ":count". The count of an extdata test is 0 if the extdata information returned is the empty string, or 1 otherwise.

section.title: Variables Namespace extdata
section.t: This document defines the variables namespace "extdata", as specified in VARIABLES, Section 3. The extdata namespace provides direct access to the data items in the external data store.

The extdata namespace accepts any identifier as variable name. A script MUST NOT fail with an error when a data item is referenced that does not exist in the external data store or otherwise cannot be retrieved. In that case the empty string will be substituted, which is analogous to the substitution of unset normal variables. Use the extdata test to evaluate wether a data item exists and can be retrieved.

This extension only concerns the retrieval of external data items and therefore it is not possible to assign values to items within the extdata variables namespace using for example the "set" action defined in VARIABLES. A script MUST fail with an error when an attempt is made to assign to an item in the extdata namespace.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Administrators should keep in mind that retrieving values from an external data store can reveal more data to a user than strictly allowed when the data store is not queried carefully.
